bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, August 26, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg discusses the inclusion of Ames in the Cornwell painting. He has contacted Kean regarding this matter.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, August 26, 1941
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
August 26, 1941.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thanks for your letter and suggested key to the Yellow
Fever picture. I have also heard from Gen. Kean who concluded
his second letter as follows:

“As regards the choice between Dr. Pinto and Dr. Ames for
the officer by the side of Cooke, my inclination would be to
take Pinto, but Ames would also be a reasonable candidate and
it would seem to be ungrateful of me to turn my thumb down on
him as he took care of me when I had yellow fever and did it
very well. I am willing to defer to my friend Truby in this
and I hope it will not help the bill that his widow (presumably
Ames) has in now to put him on the Roll of Honor where he does
not belong.”

With this approval I see not read on why we should not use
Ames' name. I called Miss Vernon, Art Director of HYGEIA on the
telephone this morning and asked her if it was too late to get
this corrected key through for the October issue. She said it
was not too late and I am sending a corrected black and white
photograph along with a copy of the key which you sent with your
letter.

We will use this same material on the insert in the JOURNAL
of the AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSOCIATION which will appear about Nov-
ember 1st.

I enjoyed your discussion of the whole problem exceedingly
and hope to answer some of your points in more detail tomorrow.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg GAK:L
Enclosures
Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester
Minnesota
